author: By     Dana Mattioli ,     Anna Wilde Mathews ,   and   Chelsey Dulaney
title: Anthem agrees to buy Cigna for $48 billion
text:
Bloomberg News Anthem is purchasing Cigna and the combined company should cover more than 53 million people. Anthem Inc. agreed to buy Cigna Corp. for more than $48 billion in a transaction that, along with a previously proposed combination of rivals, could reshape the U.S. health industry.
Under the deal’s terms, Indianapolis-based Anthem ANTM, +0.07% would pay $188 a share for Cigna, of Bloomfield, Conn., based on Anthem’s closing price on May 28. Cigna CI, +2.18% shareholders will receive $103.40 in cash and 0.5152 Anthem shares for each share held.
Including debt, the deal is valued at $54.2 billion.
The deal and its price was first reported by The Wall Street Journal earlier this week after months of speculation and contentious talks.
The combined company is expected to have $115 billion in pro forma annual revenue based on the companies’ 2015 outlooks. Anthem Chief Executive Joseph Swedish will remain chairman and CEO, while Cigna CEO David Cordani will become president and operations chief.
Anthem estimates that the deal will grow its per-share earnings by 10% in the first year after closing, with accretion more than doubling by the second year.
The tie-up of Anthem and Cigna would accelerate the rapid-fire reconfiguration at the top of the U.S. managed-care industry. The biggest companies are seeking more cost efficiency and scale as the health-care landscape changes because of the Affordable Care Act and other factors.
